Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Hospital Surgical Volume on Long-term Survival in Gastric Cancer

Background: Previous studies suggest a survival advantage for gastric cancer surgeries at high-volume hospitals, but the impact of postoperative mortality and survival factors remains unclear.

Methods: This nested volume-outcome study involved 448 surgical survivors with stage IB-IV (M0) gastric and gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma, previously randomised to adjuvant chemoradiation or surgery alone. The study assessed hospital surgical volume's effect on overall survival and gastric cancer recurrence using Medicare claims data. The primary outcome was overall survival, measured over a median follow-up of 8.9 years. Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not specified. Blinding details were not provided.

Results: Hospital surgical volume did not predict overall survival (P = 0.46) or disease-free survival (P = 0.43). Patients undergoing D1 or D2 dissection at high- or moderate-volume centers had an adjusted hazard ratio of 0.80 (95% CI, 0.53–1.20) for overall survival and 0.78 (95% CI, 0.53–1.14) for disease-free survival compared to low-volume hospitals, though not statistically significant. No survival impact was observed for D0 resections. Adverse events were not reported.

Interpretation: Hospital procedure volume had no overall effect on long-term gastric cancer survival, excluding perioperative mortality. The potential benefit of moderate- to high-volume centers for D1 or D2 dissection requires further study. Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
